sn55.12:4.2: “Mendicants, the brahmins advocate a practice called ‘get up and go’.
sn55.12:4.4: ‘Please, good people, rising early you should face east and walk.
sn55.12:4.5: Do not avoid a pit, a cliff, a stump, thorny ground, a swamp, or a sewer.
sn55.12:4.6: You should await death in the place that you fall.
sn55.12:4.7: And when your body breaks up, after death, you’ll be reborn in a good place, a heaven realm.’
sn55.12:5.1: But this practice of the brahmins is a foolish procedure, a stupid procedure. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, fading away, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, or extinguishment.
sn55.12:5.2: But in the training of the noble one I advocate a ‘get up and go’ practice
sn55.12:5.3: which does lead solely to disillusionment, fading away, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
sn55.12:6.1: And what is that get up and go practice?
sn55.12:6.4: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.12:6.9: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones …
sn55.12:6.11: This is that get up and go practice
sn55.12:6.12: which does lead solely to disillusionment, fading away, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”
